Author: Martin Sherwood
Review: Unbelievable colours here in autumn. Also the starting point of the wonderful philosopher's walk. The aquaduct is also a highlight. Well worth a visit. Crowded but still very serene and beautiful place.

Author: Evanezer Cedric (Hungryhungrymonster)
Review: one of the bigger temples with lesser tourists. i loved how scenic and quiet it was compared the the other tourist spots.

Author: Lin W
Review:
So far, this is the only temple in Kyoto that I find truly exemplifies what a temple should be like, tranquil, serene, peaceful and old. It's not flashy and not commercialized. The architecture is absolutely what you would imagine a  traditional buddhist temple should be like. Beautiful scenery, nice, quiet, and awesome buildings with architecture that can withstand thousands of years.

My favorite temple in Kyoto if not the entire Japan.

Author: Bert Kimura
Review: One of the best temple complexes to visit in Kyoto. Historic and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Best in Fall (Japanese maple or momiji) or in Spring (cherry blossoms). Spacious but crowded at these times. Nearby subtemples ($) are worthy of visits along with the Abbott's quarters. There is no charge for entry to the grounds surrounding the main gate (Sanmon). Easily accessible by walking from the Philosopher's Path or vice versa.

Author: John C
Review: A wonderful place to stroll around. Have to pay to see into some of the temples or climb the gate. It is not as crowded as some of the other temples in Kyoto and it has a beautiful garden. Highly recommended.

Author: brianksolis
Review: Great place to go for a walk or to take pictures! There are some special japanese gardens and temple viewings where you need to pay an entrance fee of 500 yen, but most of the temple area is free. Usually there are many tourists.

Author: uncle em
Review: This is among the most incredible and scenic of temples in Kyoto. It justifiably is on most must-visit lists in Kyoto. It is an absolutely magic and special place. The grounds of the complex  are beautiful and if you can come early in the morning before the crowds, you can easily have the whole place to yourself. There are many hiking trails and paths connecting with some of the other temples in the neighborhood, as well as with the hiking trail that goes around Kyoto. This is definitely one of the places to visit in Kyoto!

Author: KahFui Lim
Review:
Zen Buddhism, a practical experience, a way of life in simplicity and balance. We are here to pay our respects and well wishes in one of the more important Zen temple of Kyoto.

A saying goes by a moment of prayer in ÂçóÁ¶ÖÂØ∫ worthy of a year of well wishing. Aside from being off-the-tourist radar, the temple full of presence in calm and tranquility. Never been feeling so spiritually and mentally connected to the force of Zen.

Author: Cadee Qiu
Review: Absolutely loved visiting this place, it's a must see in Kyoto.  There are really wonderful temples and gardens and everything is so peaceful here. Visit a couple of the paid gardens and temples if you have time because it's absolutely worth it. It's very nice to just walk around and be in touch with nature.

Author: bernard willis
Review: One of my favorites temples ever, strikingly beautiful in its simplicity.  Also surrounded by several other sites worth seeing so great spot to check out to see a lot with minimal walking.

Author: Marwan ElGhamrawy
Review: A must see temple if you are ever in Kyoto. Nanzen-ji is a Zen Buddhist temple. It was established in 1291. It was destroyed by fire 3 times until finally rebuilt again in 1597.

Author: Francesco Leardini
Review: Beautiful temple in a wonderful garden. We visited it in Autumn when the maple trees were at their best peak colour. Und it was full of tourists making it less attractive, but absolutely worth to visit if you are in Kyoto.

Author: Sarah Kellie
Review: My favorite Temple in Kyoto.  I loved the Hojo garden and sliding doors.  Just stunning! I learned so much about Japanese history.  There is a free WiFi tour that you can connect to your smartphone.  Be sure to bring your headphones!

Author: Annalisa Littleton
Review: This is a rather large temple complex and the day we visited it was pretty busy. If you are looking for a relaxing experience, I would not recommend visiting during cherry blossom season. It was very crowded around Nanzenji Temple. Once you started going to the sub temples around Nanzenji it was less crowded. It was beautiful, but I would have enjoyed it more if it has been a little less crowded.

Author: Dari Schulz
Review: Compared to a lot of places in Kyoto, it was a more calm place with a lot to see. It has many temple areas, a huge aqueduct, some exhibitions, gardens.. Entry into the garden at the pictures was only 300 yen per person and it was really quiet and beautiful. Not super large but you could watch a lot of small animals like birds, lizards or fish in, around or near the pond.

Author: MeT
Review: A truly Zen setting n highly recommended. Located within the Nanzenjifukuchicho temple, it‚Äôs an aqueduct built in ancient Roman architecture styling and a short stroll away from the main temple structure. It‚Äôs defunct now n the remains are purely for viewing. It‚Äôs a serene area, moss covered n lush with vegetation. Together with the tall trees, cool temperatures and a small stream of water that provides a truly scenic spot for quiet contemplation. The area has clearly been conserved n maintained and much of the original look has been preserved. It‚Äôs a unique structure to find in a forested area at a Japanese Zen Temple site but truly a gem, well worth a closer examination. Well recommendedüëç

Author: Michael Mosser
Review: On everyone‚Äôs ‚Äúmust-see‚Äù list in Kyoto, for obvious reasons. We went early via taxi from our hotel in central Kyoto, and it was about a ¬•2000 ride. Once there, we particularly appreciated the Zen garden, and the grounds surrounding the main temple, as that‚Äôs more our speed than visiting the insides of temples. We loved the aqueduct and the upper grounds as well, and found the crowds to be manageable. A very pleasant experience and a great way to start the day.

Author: Matthew
Review:
Beautiful grounds with various options to explore:
Visiting the Nanzen-ji Temple was a surprisingly calm jewel on our trip to Kyoto.  The large grounds have various temples, a very large gate, gardens, an aqueduct and more!  General access is free, with certain areas requiring entrance fees, depending on your interests & time to spend there.  Located on the edge of the mountains, this is a great location to spend a slow-paced morning, or whole day if you want to explore all the areas.

Author: Jacob Rothschild
Review:
Beautiful Temple a little bit outside of Gion. You can go there by Bus or Subway. There is a nice Garden where you can enter for 500¬•.
The Aqueduct is pretty nice and you can take good pictures under it. If you take the steps on the right side you will find yourself in a pretty forest where you can walk around and if your lucky you can see some Monkeys (that's what they say on the signs)

Author: kitz kirti
Review: Lovely and peaceful place for people who wants to visit the temple...awesome place and awesome experience love to be around peace....full of greenery and garden...nice place to meditate...history of these tenples are mangnificent....

Author: Jet Sng
Review: There are a few spots in this place with entrance fees, each with its own unique charm. It's recommended to come here during autumn, as the temple is surrounded by trees. Do take your time to appreciate the complex, as it is quite nicely laid out and is great for anyone that just wants to take it easy.

Author: Â∞èÁªµÁªµ
Review: the architecture is breathtaking - it's stupendously enormous yet intricately built in wood and maintained until today! it's also surrounded by Japanese pine and maple trees so it's another lovely place to visit in the fall. the steps are mad steep too üòÇ but lovely to visit and grab some photos!

Author: Michael Chang
Review: The temple looks absolutely beautiful with its architecture. It's massive and in the center. There are also many other buildings that share the same design and looks just as good. The day I went, there was something happening in the temple. I don't want to say what I thought it was, to not sound ignorant, but it was quite interesting. You can also go up one of the buildings, but it cost money and I did not believe it was worth it.

Author: Fl√°via Giomo
Review:
Kyoto is impressive, and so the Nanzenji Temple.
Take time to visit it, and enjoy the silent and zen atmosphere.
Whenever visiting Kyoto, make sure you wear confy shoes... you will have a lot of walk, and on the zen temples you need to take your shoes off before entering it. Which is quite relaxing to walk on bare feet on wood floor.
Nanzenji is one of the must go places in Kyoto.
The Sanmon gate also in the same compound is impressive. Go all the way to the top, you will watch the city, and you will have a little view of the buildings on the compound that are not open for tourists, maybe were the monges enjoy their day? Who knows?

The aqueduct is also cool for instagram pictures.

Author: Maddy Berkman
Review: I had an incredible visit!! The grounds were crowded but when we entered the main temple building and accompanying gardens we had the place to ourselves! I'd love to visit again.

Author: J May
Review: Beautiful temple, stunning location. A video playing near the beginning of the building (with English subtitles) provided much useful historical information.

Author: Walla Xia
Review: A hot tourist spot but crowded with a lot of visitors. It took me more than one hr by bus from Kyoto Station to here due to heavy traffic jam during the Nov holiday.

Author: Greg Walters
Review:
Large amount of free space,  multiple payed gardens and of course,  the aqueduct.
The aqueduct can be seen from the ground,  and there are excellent places to shoot photos beneath the arches.
There are two paths to views of the top,  bit many are obstructed due to repairs.
Use the bathrooms by the garden,  and enter from the north to avoid the tour groups.

Author: Maria Knithaki
Review: Here you can find a lot of little temples, its with own unique aesthetic. Worth visiting the complex. Also the old train line crosss from here and there is a hiking path with monkeys. Definitely you have to visit this place if you are  in Kyoto. Really peaceful and provides with a couple of activities

Author: Camila Frias
Review: My favorite place in Kyoto. It's a true pleasure to walk the grounds. Everything is quite and peaceful. You have to pay a very reasonable entrance fee to visit the inside of the buildings but the exterior is by far the best part of the experience. In the entrance, there's a Blue Bottle coffee that's very pretty so make sure to check it out.

Author: Cameron Tynes
Review: Amazing temple complex with a 2-story temple gate that you can actually go to the top of. The complex itself is free to get into, but like most temple complexes in Japan, you have to pay if you want to go into a garden or building itself. At Nanzen-ji we chose to pay to go up into the gate and had stunning views. The stairs into the upper deck of the gate are very steep, but there are adequate handrails. You have to take your shoes off to go to the top, but they provide you with a bag to carry them in.

Author: Hiroki Kobayashi
Review: Well described famous site, must visit. Sunset is magically beautiful here.

Author: Jean-Fran√ßois Bergeon
Review: Next to Nanzenji Temple, a really picturesque Aqueduct. If you pass under the bridge and climb the stairs, you won't be able to walk on the Aqueduct itself, but you can have access to the canal upstream of the Aqueduct. There is a nice walk there!

Author: Kay Pepper
Review: This is a interesting temple to visit, the areas you are allowed to walk around gives you a very good image of temple life for a monk. You can view the rooms and how they prep the zen garden, it gives you a sense peace. The grounds are beautiful, full of lush greenery. There is a lot to look at here and I would recommend you adding this place to your travel list, but I would think most people would want to visit every single temple while they are in Kyoto!

Author: Iwa He
Review: Nanzenji Temple is my favorite place in Kyoto.  I want to go again.

Author: Ryo
Review: In its premises you can enjoy classic and gorgeous looking of Buddhist temple building, historical brick aqueduct, Japanese style gardens, and gigantic main gate ‚Äî which you can enter and enjoy the view from the upper floor, that is amazing. A lot of trees are also there. You can enjoy cherry blossom in Spring as well as autumn leaves. After walking around this and somewhere else ‚Äî so many places to visit!! - you can rest at Bluebottle nearby.

Author: Bohya Kinema
Review: One of the most famous temple Nanzen-Ji exists near from Keage Incline, Hydrophobic system for Kyoto electric street car from 1895 to 1978. The water road passes through in the temple without unnaturalness, good photo spot at all. No explanations is required if once visited!

Author: Enzo Wong
Review: Feels like time traveled to ancient china, Japan did a great job protecting historical buildings.

Author: Josh Diddams
Review: Super cool location for seeing an aqueduct and the first gate I recall ever being able to enter (for a small fee). Worth it!

Author: Jeremy T
Review: It would be impossible to visit every temple even within Kyoto, with a limited time frame this is a worthwhile visit if you're in the area. I went specifically to see the zen garden and it didn't disappoint. It's a large open space and the level of commitment, patience and discipline to pick up every leaf and branch and then re-rake and re-shape that entire space on a daily basis is nothing short of remarkable and inspiring. The rest of the temple grounds are beautiful and just as well landscaped but one can just sit and appreciate the zen garden and it wouldn't be  considered as time wasted.

Author: Mike Albrecht
Review: We went in looking to see temple but I ended up being fascinated by the working Aqueduct quite amazing to see it from above and below and there was a trail where you could walk along the Aqueduct at the top I followed it for awhile and saw some great views of Kyoto and the Temple but I the end ran out of time and had to head back. Recommend going to see while I  Kyoto.

Author: Adams_coffee
Review: One of the most incredible gardens and temple complexes in Kyoto. Cannot recommend this place enough. Incredible views, amazing gardens, special atmosphere.

Author: Chefman
Review:
Beautiful temple, terrible administration. There are admission fees to enter EVERYWHERE and they range from 400-600 yen per. If you want to visit every place in the complex it'll cost you around 3000 yen. Absolutely ridiculous.
I've visited almost every major temple in Kansai and this is the greediest one by far

Author: Nathan Chen
Review: Won‚Äôt place this as a top priority, but a nice walk if you have time.

Author: Sei One
Review: It was a wonderful and beautiful spot. I went there during autumn leaf season.

Author: Ben Bethel
Review: Always a wonderful visit when in Kyoto... Would be nice to have a timed entry that includes tea ceremony, visits to inside chambers, a meditation practice... I dislike that people are there to take pictures and leave, instead of taking it in and staying for a while.

Author: Matthew Ng
Review:
Any shrine and temples in Kyoto is a few hundred years ago. Nanzen ji clusters of tempers and shrines are no different.
Majestic and simply awesome.
There are a few shrines and temples around this area. And further up a short walk of maybe ten minutes is another famous shrine Eikando ji.

Author: Goi Kasemjaiprasong
Review: Don't missed , nice temple less of tourists

Author: TED
Review: It's interesting to see water flows north!  (Dec. 2022)

Author: Pattara Kiatisevi
Review: Serenely atmosphere, nature and culture. Big viaduct.

Author: Christian Jensen
Review: Fantastic temple with bonus aqueduct. You can take the path along the aqueduct through the forest. Especially nice at dusk.

Author: Seo Jung Park
Review: Beautiful place to visit. There was not many people around here but if you are around this area, you should visit and enjoy the scenery here. Great place to take cute photos too.

Author: Elizabeth Barlow
Review: Nice temple, really big. There is an aqueduct in the grounds of the temple. You can walk round the grounds for free but you have to pay to go inside the various temple buildings. Worth a visit.

Author: RY
Review: came here Nanzenji in fall. of course fall is cool, but other seasons is also good vo come.

Author: Shukri Zaki
Review: Nanzenji is a Buddhist temple in Kyoto. The temple itself is not that impressive, but the gate is worth going up to explore the view around. There are three part of the temple that you have to pay to see which will cost you in total 1600 yen per person, but for me it's only worth the money for the gate.

Author: Jian Lu
Review:
+ Amazing scenery. Japanese maples and dry garden (ÊûØÂ±±Ê∞¥Ôºâ
+ What‚Äôs most amazing for me and much less talked about for Nanzan-Ji, is the aqueduct system from the lake Biwa (ÁêµÁê∂Êπñ) canal. I really didn‚Äôt expect this in Japan. Besides observing it from the ground, you can also walk to the top and walk on a small part of it.

Author: Elizabeth Cheng
Review: This is a very quiet and peaceful temple. You don‚Äôt see too many tourists here. And it‚Äôs very easy to get to. The walk leading up to the temple was a nice stroll as well.

Author: Emily Nguyen
Review: Highlight of our trip to Kyoto. There‚Äôs a family of aggressive monkeys that live behind. Please don‚Äôt look them directly in the eye. We will return again next time. Very sultry.

Author: William Schleier
Review: Where to begin‚Ä¶we love functional architecture and this aqueduct was the perfect accent note on our honeymoon. There are several places to view the flowing water from. One of these is a pagoda with a decent hike behind it. Simply excellent.

Author: MH Yang
Review: The tea house next to the entrance is very peaceful and comfortable. If you have the visiting ticket, the sweet plus tea will be 500 yen extra. You will be impressed by the painting, garden and buildings.

Author: Reese Des
Review:
It's nice to finally see a place you can actually enter.
However I hate the fact they won't let you leave your shoes at the entrance, you have to take an unnecessary and contaminating non reusable plastic bag and you have to carry them, so gl if you are wearing heavy boots. Also you have to take the bag with you since there is no trashcan so now you have to go around the city joining the challenging adventure of the search of a trashcan.

Author: Vivian S.
Review: Our favorite temple in all of Kyoto. very zen and beautiful even in the off season without fall foliage. The tea room looked so inviting we had to get some amazing matcha and traditional cookie (500 pp). Amazing art in the walls of this expansive temple. Walking around looking at the gardens was such a treat. Not too crowded on a weekday morning. Gorgeous all around and the aqueduct was really photogenic too.  We prefer this over Nijo castle any day.

Author: Heidi
Review: definitely a hidden gems in the temples! It is unlike the temples around and built with bricks and arcs.

Author: Matthew Khew
Review:
Nansen-ji is one of the well known temples in Kyoto.

There is a huge Sanmon (mountain gate) in front of the temple, visitors can climb up to the mezzanine floor with paid tickets.

Not much buildings for visitors except for the main hall in this temple areas.

Visitors usually paid more attention to the aqueduct a few steps next to the temple hall.

Couples and ladies in kimono like photo taking here, therefore a little bit busy here

Author: Adrien D
Review: Loved this one. The visit is short but this is very beautiful.

Author: Em U
Review: On top of this aqueduct is a little known route between Keage Station and Nanzen Temple.  So if you‚Äôve taken the usual streets to visit the temple and want a more hidden trek back to the metro,  just follow the stairs up then simply go along the waterway. It will lead you to the picturesque former railway tracks at Keage Station.

Author: Joanne Elkadi
Review: Came here on a rainy day and it was still beautiful, especially with the cherry blossoms. Definitely recommend going up the gate and entering the temple itself.

Author: xImanndli
Review: You need to visit this place as a foreigner!üòä

Author: Niek de Greef
Review: Very nice temple complex. Climb up the port for a nice view over the city.

Author: Brian Lin
Review: We were there early December and a bit late into the maple leaves season, so a lot of leaves have fallen, but it was still beautiful. Could only imagine how gorgeous it would be during peak season.

Author: Ken Teh
Review:
Beautiful and great place to enjoy autumn..
You can take photo everywhere within the area.. be early to avoid the crowd..

Author: Linda Sloan
Review: Sprawling site with lots to see! The gate is amazing,  as are the painted screens inside the main hall.

Author: „Ç∑„Éß„Éº„Éò„ÉºÊù±„Éï„É™
Review: In Japan, there are so many temples, but I think Nanzenji is the best, no matter when you go!

Author: Bruce Tiew
Review: This is a very beautiful temple.  It has meditation class offer to public.  A serene place to visit to calm down mind and spirit.

Author: Lamb201210
Review: I think this is one of the most worthwhile temples to visit in Kyoto.

Author: YY
Review:
Quite a huge temple, with some Sakura trees in it üå∏ there‚Äôs an incense offering which was rare to see, given that most temples have its door closed off without any incense involved.

The serenity was also to be appreciated, it‚Äôs almost like a park in itself - compared to where we came from where a temple is pretty much compact and solely for praying purposes.

Author: Serene
Review: Wanted to visit the Nanzen-Ji temple but not sure why it was closed earlier than the supposed time. No love lost, this bridge seems more interesting than the temple, Was there around 4pm, crowd was not too bad, but it is difficult to get a shot without anyone in the background especially under the bridge where you can see the arches. Would be possible to get a nice shot if you go early in the morning

Author: Sigitas Vilkas
Review: We went there while rainning - and were the only ones. Relaxing and calm!

Author: Yorick van de Haar
Review: Lovely temple close-by a water source and installation, and it was our start of long amazing hike in the mountains with hints of monks maintaining the mountain trails with meditation spots and shrines

Author: F S
Review: The whole temple grounds are impressive but the entrance to hojo garden is steep at 600jpy and it's ridiculous when they not only ask you to carry your shoes in a plastic bag but also don't provide a trash can for the plastic bag but instead tell you do take the shoe bag home (?!). I would expect the emitter of plastic bags to provide the recycling box themselves...

Author: skyberries
Review: The entire precinct is designated as a national historic site.

Author: Diancheng Hu
Review: Could be peaceful and beautiful even during busy season. So far the best temple I've visited in this area!

Author: Sebastien H.
Review: An atypical place for a Buddhist temple, English heritage for its bricks and its structure, this viaduct with multiple arches and hollow pillars becomes the ideal place for photography for lovers ‚ô•Ô∏è

Author: Rory Rosszell
Review: Despite having visited many of the temples in Kyoto over the years, this was my first visit to Nanzenji, and I obviously should have visited sooner! The massive main gate is quite impressive, and it is certainly worth paying to go up and view the grounds from there. It was raining the day we visited, but the roof of the gate keeps you dry as you wander around, and in many ways the rain made the trees even more beautiful.

Author: Ros Fomin
Review: The garden is beautiful and worth the travel to and view it. Take some time to be calm here. You can easily find it from the bus stop and it is very worth the value of the small ticket fee.

Author: Francis Lau Yik Sin
Review: One of my favourite shrines in central Kyoto, and it is less crowded as well.

Author: Gunnar Caya
Review:
The temple and the grounds in general are really nice. The main gates and halls are nice, but pretty typical of other temples in Kyoto.

What sets this temple apart is the fact that if you stray a little bit outside of the main temple area, you can see some pretty unique scenery. A small aqueduct carrying water, a ton of trees, and a hill with a small pagoda up top, connected to forest trails that are scenic (and have monkeys if you're into that).

The garden here is decent, though 400 yen is a lot for what there is to see. You can also climb the steps of the gate for an even higher fee to get views of the surrounding area. But even if you decide not to spend any money, you can still see some really cool scenery here. I'd highly recommend seeing this in conjunction with the Higashiyama Jisho-ji/Ginkakuji Temple and walking from one to the other along the Philosopher's Path

Author: Vasana Bija
Review: A great place for learning the essential sprit of Zen and art of gardening

Author: ichi _
Review: definitely a must see when you‚Äôre in Kyoto - absolutely beautiful

Author: Khalid S
Review: Pretty area to walk around. Not quite as impressive nor peaceful as some of the temples north and south of it though. Tons of little flies trying to attack your eyes!

Author: Liisa Stenberg
Review: Huge temple area with lots and lots to see. Be sure to visit the main gate from where you can see nicely around the area and the view over the city. The main hall is also worth a see: there are interesting buildings and you get to wander around the temple corridors filled with beautiful art. I recommed a visit on a weekday, so it is not too crowded.

Author: ÊÖßÂêõÊ±ü
Review: A relaxing and beautiful place

Author: Hiromi Willingham
Review: A beautiful and sacred place!  I highly recommend that you pay the entrance fee to claim up the inside of the gate.

Author: Ruben Royackers
Review: Old temples with an aquaduct.

Author: Miz Pre
Review: The cobble stones are from the anceint times. It was cool to walk and explore traditional neighborhoods

Author: Jonathan Cottrell
Review: It‚Äôs quite the sight to behold when walking up the street‚Äîor from any angle, actually. The pagoda itself isn‚Äôt much to walk around, but the streets surrounding it are well worth the visit.

Author: Philipp
Review: Only visit the free part. If you Go up the mountain. You‚Äòll find a beautiful waterspring.

Author: Niklas Brendel
Review: A wonderful Temple with  beautiful nature, it was a very peaceful and great experience üåø

Author: Colin Taylor
Review: An off-the-beaten path Buddhist temple that isn‚Äôt overrun with crowds. The garden is a must-see if you go to Kyoto. It‚Äôs quiet and serene. It‚Äôs what Buddhist temples appear to be in the movies.

Author: Vignesh Selvasundar
Review: A cool Buddhist Zen temple that was very peaceful. The garden was amazing and you can immediately feel the temperature drop with so much greenery around you.
